title: Unexpected rustc panic

labels.name: I-ICE
labels.description: Issue: The compiler panicked, giving an Internal Compilation Error (ICE) ❄️

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

labels.name: E-needs-mcve
labels.description: Call for participation: This issue needs a Minimal Complete and Verifiable Example

body:
I was modifying my Cargo.toml file, when I have commented 2 lines of it, representing the crates `tokio-utils` and `tokio-stream`, the compiler unexpectedly panicked.

This is my Cargo.toml file:

    [package]
    name = "turdb"
    version = "0.1.0"
    edition = "2021"

    [dependencies]
    tokio = { version = "1.2.21", features = ["full"] }
    #tokio-stream = { version = "0.1.11", features = ["net"] }
    #tokio-util = { version = "0.7.4", features = ["full"] }
    serde = { version = "1.0.144", features = ["derive"] }
    nix = { version = "0.25.0", features = ["signal"] }
    log = { version = "0.4", features = ["max_level_trace", "release_max_level_info"] }
    clap = { version = "4.0.19", features = ["derive"] }
    env_logger = "0.9.1"
    daemonize = "0.4.1"
    toml = "0.5"
    paste = "0.1.5"
    bytes = "1.1.0"
    num_cpus = "1.13.1"
    proctitle = "0.1.1"
    futures = "0.3.24"
    chrono = "0.4"
    home = "0.5.4"
    rpassword = "7.0.0"
    dirs = "4.0.0"


I completely removed those '#'-marked lines, but I left them here with '#' so you can see them.
When I typed `cargo build` again, after removing them, this was the rustc output:
````
$  cargo build

error: internal compiler error: unexpected panic

note: the compiler unexpectedly panicked. this is a bug.

note: we would appreciate a bug report: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/new?labels=C-bug%2C+I-ICE%2C+T-compiler&template=ice.md

note: rustc 1.65.0 (897e37553 2022-11-02) running on x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu

note: compiler flags: --crate-type lib -C embed-bitcode=no -C debuginfo=2 -C incremental=[REDACTED]

note: some of the compiler flags provided by cargo are hidden

query stack during panic:
#0 [analysis] running analysis passes on this crate
end of query stack
error: could not compile `turdb`
````

Hope this helps!
